Hopkins Raises Pay Scale to Stay Competitive
The University has increased the pay of all full—time,
non-professional workers, bringing the minimum wage
rate up to $2.10 per hour.
According to a memorandum from the office of Robert
F. Kerley, Vice President for Administration, these employees' wages were increased to "bring their compensation to a competitive level based on local prevailing
pay rates and benefit practices."
All craft, service and maintenance employees,designated as Position Classification Series 800, will be
granted a wage increase of twenty-five cents an hour,
except where it is necessary to grant larger increases
in order to bring employees salaries up to the minimum
of $2.10 per hour. All employees in this category will
now be paid on a weekly basis.

Salary Changes
Other non-professional employees, including clerical
and secretarial workers, and lab assistants, will also
receive salary adjustments, on a somewhat different
scale. All employees in these categories earning less
than $4100 per year will have their salaries raised to
$4100 per year. Since these employees work a 37 1/2
hour week, the $4100 figure represents a wage of $2.10
per hour.
In addition, each Dean or Administrative officer will
be allowed to grant increases over $4100 per year to
employees in this latter category. According to Kerley's
memorandum, this must be done "withinthe constraints"
of current budgetary limitations, to maintain competitiveness with prevailing area salary levels and to re-

All of the salary increases, except the last one, are
retroactive to January 1, 1970. In the latter case, the
date an increase becomes effective will be at the discretion of the Dean or Administrative officer making
the salary adjustment.

Fringe Benefits
The University has further authorized the extension of
employee benefits.. Effective March 1, the University will
pay the full cost of a Blue Cross/Blue Shield family plan
insurance package, and of a Group Life Insurance Coverage. This provides life insurance to employees in the
amount of their annual salaries, rounded down to the
nearest $1,000.
An additional benefit involves the new pension plan,
which the University will fund. The details of the plan
have yet to be worked out.
Vice President Kerley stated that these increases are
"substantially the same as those at the Hopkins Hospital."
Hospital, and workers at both institutions will get a
new pension plan.
These actions apply to all segments of the University
with the exception of the School of Advanced International Studies and the Applied Physics Laboratory.
The way for these increases was cleared when the two
unions which are attempting to represent Hopkins employees, 1199E and Local 1231 of the Laborers International Union, AFL-CIO, stated that they had no objection

Time is Running Out
Two of the most important issues on campus these days, the discipline
controversy and the question of future housing facilities for undergraduate
women, both show very clearly that the greatest problem that Homewood
faces is a lack of decent administratiye procedural policy, or what is commonly referred to as governance.
The governance issue is by its very nature an extremely broad one, and
none of the groups now involved in the debate over its various aspects have
gotten very far in delineating its reaches. The two above-mentioned issues,
however, help somewhat to point out what a decent governance proposal
must take into account.
First, on the discipline conflict, it has become obvious to many as the
controversy continues, that much of the acrimony on both side stems
from personal factors and political in-fighting rather than an honest attempt to reach an amicable and satisfactory settlement. The President
feels that Arts and Sciences, in contradistinction to the other divisions, is
trying to politically outmaneuver him and is acting in bad faith in dealing
with his essentially fair and democratic proposition. Members of the Student Affairs Committee and its supporters contend that Gordon, after a
brief flirt with procedural orthodoxy, is reverting back to his 'usual'
authoritarianism and arbitrariness.
No one seems to be questioning why, in the first place, such a strange
and complicated method of drawing up a Conduct Code was decided upon.
Is it really necessary for such a document to go through four almost unrelated steps before it is adopted? The President first appointed an ad hoc
Arts and Sciences committee to draw up a University-wide draft. Then he
rewrote the draft. Then he sent it to the four divisions for approval. One refused to consider it, two accepted outright and the last rewrote it again.
He then rejected the rewrite, but added the note that he would give consideration to any petition drive which included the signatures of at least
25% of the group involved. He later stated that he would only give consideration to such a petition if it contains specific recommendations and arguments to prove its point.

Polarization Sets In
,Small wonder, then, that everyone blames the other side for its actions.
Small wonder, too, that accusations of "bad faith" rise in every direction.
The result of such a complicated procedure is that there are three different
petitions circulating on the Homewood campus at this time, none of
which is even attempting to match up to Gordon's criteria that it must
contain new arguments. Polarization of positions is setting in.
The question that comes to mind now--and should have been asked
earlier—is what higher good has this complicated situation accomplished?
Why was an ad hoc committee chosen in the first place? Why, with the
exception of Dr. Bevan, was it comprised of Arts and Sciences personnel
only? Is there a real need for a University-wide Conduct Code? Is the
Student Affairs Committee to be generally considered representative of
the students and faculty on this campus? If not, why was Gordon's draft
turned over to that body for consideration? If so, why does Gordon demand that a petition drive be mounted above and beyond the widelyknown protests of the Committee?
Obviously, something is very wrong. The group which drew up the
original proposal last summer should have been set up as a subcommittee
of a standing committee so that it could be consulted and dealt with as a
permanent, responsible body and not one which has long since faded from
sight. This subcommittee should then have assured itself and Dr. Gordon
of its status as a representative group one way or the other—either that its
findings were definitely accepted by a majority on the Homewood campus or that they were merely personal opinions and not necessarily typical.
In the first case, the President might have been safe had he released a
unilateral, non-negotiable statement, for he would have known that he was
backed by much of the community. In the second case, he would have had
little choice but to put his draft up to a vote among the entire student and
faculty population. If he decided that he wanted the proposal to stand for
the entire University he would have had to put the document up for
separate vote on each of the other three campuses.
The way things now stand, the ad hoc committee, by its very dissolution, has lost any say in the matter, Dean Kimball, by passing the President's charge on to the SAC, has also given up his say in the proceedings.
The faculty, apparently only peripherally interested in the discipline issue
in the first place, has nevertheless been the traditionally dominant force at

Homewood and does not like to see major questions bypass its review.
And the SAC, a young and relatively overlooked group, has opened itself
up to criticism as to how pure its motives are in a continuing battle to fill a
power vacuum. The President, the deans, the students and the faculty are
left standing in the cold, able only to hurl accusations and petitions at one
another. The real question of who is being represented and who is being
arbitrary is left by the wayside.
Now to the second "burning issue"—housing for undergraduate females.
This question is not as complex as the preceding one, nor it has reached
the 'crisis' stage where all participants are reduced to name calling aod
denial of responsibility. Yet, considering the fact that few can see any
reason for a conflict over such a seemingly noncontroversial issue to occur,
the overtones of the strife are quite disconcerting.

The Task Force
When the Board of Trustees approved coeducation in November, it asked for the creation of a Task Force to look into all the ramifications of
such a move, one of which was housing. The Task Force submitted three
proposals, all of which were rejected for lack of funds. A fourth, proposed
in January and involving McCoy Hall, was recently accepted by the President, althought there was a certain amount of opposition voiced by graduate students.
At the same time, the ubiquitious Student Affairs Committee had charged its Subcommittee on Housing with looking into the same problem, and
had arrived at a solution which would have led to a modest refurbishment
of several of the freshman dorms, a proposal which was obviously more to
the liking of both dorm students and graduate students. This proposal,
originally endorsed but later dropped by Dean Swanson, has been ignored
by the administation on various pretexts: that it was too late. that it
merely threw a cog into the "smooth-functioning" machinery of the Task
Force, and so on.
The disturbing aspects of the conflict are not so much whether one
proposal is intrinsically 'better' than the other, but rather how such an
overlapping of administrative responsibility is allowed—and consistently
allowed—to occur. Although all of us should be concerned that the most
conscientious committees and individuals be chosen to do exploratory
work, and that the most competent suggestions be accepted, it is clear that
in a very real sense Johns Hopkins has not even reached this level of
sophistication. We are not able, even at this critical stage, to determine
definilively which campus group should deal with a given problem.
It is in this spirit of conern that the News-Letter demands that the
faculty, as the ruling force at Homewood, move with utmost haste and
diligence toward finalization of plans for a comprehensive renovation of
the governance procedures on campus. Only then will the University be
able to move forward smoothly, quickly and competently.

Time is Running Out
Two of the most important issues on campus these days, the discipline
controversy and the question of future housing facilities for undergraduate
women, both show very clearly that the greatest problem that Homewood
faces is a lack of decent administratiye procedural policy, or what is commonly referred to as governance.
The governance issue is by its very nature an extremely broad one, and
none of the groups now involved in the debate over its various aspects have
gotten very far in delineating its reaches. The two above-mentioned issues,
however, help somewhat to point out what a decent governance proposal
must take into account.
First, on the discipline conflict, it has become obvious to many as the
controversy continues, that much of the acrimony on both side stems
from personal factors and political in-fighting rather than an honest attempt to reach an amicable and satisfactory settlement. The President
feels that Arts and Sciences, in contradistinction to the other divisions, is
trying to politically outmaneuver him and is acting in bad faith in dealing
with his essentially fair and democratic proposition. Members of the Student Affairs Committee and its supporters contend that Gordon, after a
brief flirt with procedural orthodoxy, is reverting back to his 'usual'
authoritarianism and arbitrariness.
No one seems to be questioning why, in the first place, such a strange
and complicated method of drawing up a Conduct Code was decided upon.
Is it really necessary for such a document to go through four almost unrelated steps before it is adopted? The President first appointed an ad hoc
Arts and Sciences committee to draw up a University-wide draft. Then he
rewrote the draft. Then he sent it to the four divisions for approval. One refused to consider it, two accepted outright and the last rewrote it again.
He then rejected the rewrite, but added the note that he would give consideration to any petition drive which included the signatures of at least
25% of the group involved. He later stated that he would only give consideration to such a petition if it contains specific recommendations and arguments to prove its point.

Polarization Sets In
,Small wonder, then, that everyone blames the other side for its actions.
Small wonder, too, that accusations of "bad faith" rise in every direction.
The result of such a complicated procedure is that there are three different
petitions circulating on the Homewood campus at this time, none of
which is even attempting to match up to Gordon's criteria that it must
contain new arguments. Polarization of positions is setting in.
The question that comes to mind now--and should have been asked
earlier—is what higher good has this complicated situation accomplished?
Why was an ad hoc committee chosen in the first place? Why, with the
exception of Dr. Bevan, was it comprised of Arts and Sciences personnel
only? Is there a real need for a University-wide Conduct Code? Is the
Student Affairs Committee to be generally considered representative of
the students and faculty on this campus? If not, why was Gordon's draft
turned over to that body for consideration? If so, why does Gordon demand that a petition drive be mounted above and beyond the widelyknown protests of the Committee?
Obviously, something is very wrong. The group which drew up the
original proposal last summer should have been set up as a subcommittee
of a standing committee so that it could be consulted and dealt with as a
permanent, responsible body and not one which has long since faded from
sight. This subcommittee should then have assured itself and Dr. Gordon
of its status as a representative group one way or the other—either that its
findings were definitely accepted by a majority on the Homewood campus or that they were merely personal opinions and not necessarily typical.
In the first case, the President might have been safe had he released a
unilateral, non-negotiable statement, for he would have known that he was
backed by much of the community. In the second case, he would have had
little choice but to put his draft up to a vote among the entire student and
faculty population. If he decided that he wanted the proposal to stand for
the entire University he would have had to put the document up for
separate vote on each of the other three campuses.
The way things now stand, the ad hoc committee, by its very dissolution, has lost any say in the matter, Dean Kimball, by passing the President's charge on to the SAC, has also given up his say in the proceedings.
The faculty, apparently only peripherally interested in the discipline issue
in the first place, has nevertheless been the traditionally dominant force at

Homewood and does not like to see major questions bypass its review.
And the SAC, a young and relatively overlooked group, has opened itself
up to criticism as to how pure its motives are in a continuing battle to fill a
power vacuum. The President, the deans, the students and the faculty are
left standing in the cold, able only to hurl accusations and petitions at one
another. The real question of who is being represented and who is being
arbitrary is left by the wayside.
Now to the second "burning issue"—housing for undergraduate females.
This question is not as complex as the preceding one, nor it has reached
the 'crisis' stage where all participants are reduced to name calling aod
denial of responsibility. Yet, considering the fact that few can see any
reason for a conflict over such a seemingly noncontroversial issue to occur,
the overtones of the strife are quite disconcerting.

The Task Force
When the Board of Trustees approved coeducation in November, it asked for the creation of a Task Force to look into all the ramifications of
such a move, one of which was housing. The Task Force submitted three
proposals, all of which were rejected for lack of funds. A fourth, proposed
in January and involving McCoy Hall, was recently accepted by the President, althought there was a certain amount of opposition voiced by graduate students.
At the same time, the ubiquitious Student Affairs Committee had charged its Subcommittee on Housing with looking into the same problem, and
had arrived at a solution which would have led to a modest refurbishment
of several of the freshman dorms, a proposal which was obviously more to
the liking of both dorm students and graduate students. This proposal,
originally endorsed but later dropped by Dean Swanson, has been ignored
by the administation on various pretexts: that it was too late. that it
merely threw a cog into the "smooth-functioning" machinery of the Task
Force, and so on.
The disturbing aspects of the conflict are not so much whether one
proposal is intrinsically 'better' than the other, but rather how such an
overlapping of administrative responsibility is allowed—and consistently
allowed—to occur. Although all of us should be concerned that the most
conscientious committees and individuals be chosen to do exploratory
work, and that the most competent suggestions be accepted, it is clear that
in a very real sense Johns Hopkins has not even reached this level of
sophistication. We are not able, even at this critical stage, to determine
definilively which campus group should deal with a given problem.
It is in this spirit of conern that the News-Letter demands that the
faculty, as the ruling force at Homewood, move with utmost haste and
diligence toward finalization of plans for a comprehensive renovation of
the governance procedures on campus. Only then will the University be
able to move forward smoothly, quickly and competently.
